image.altText: Inside UN general assembly world leaders sit at desks watching podium - wide shot

props.synopsis: World leaders converge in New York City for the biggest gathering of global decision-makers since COVID. Here are some takeaways from day one of this year's UN General Assembly meeting.

title.children: 'Our world is becoming unhinged': Here's what happened on day one of the UN's big annual meeting

image.altText: Image from Twitter of New York Times ad.

props.synopsis: Over 200 climate scientists have taken out a full-page ad in the New York Times calling out Australia's "climate annihilation", while Fijian activists impacted by rising sea levels urge Canberra to do more.

title.children: Scientists take out full-page New York Times ad calling on Australia to end ‘climate annihilation’

image.altText: 2020-03-19T000000Z_1275000883_RC20NF9L2E4F_RTRMADP_3_HEALTH-CORONAVIRUS (2)

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Victoria introduces 7.5 per cent levy on short-stay rentals. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia has given up the fight to eradicate a deadly bee parasite known as the varroa mite, agreeing to move to a management plan. About 30,000 hives have been euthanased by authorities since varroa mite was detected 15 months ago in sentinel hives at the Port of Newcastle in New South Wales. The $132 million varroa response plan was the largest biosecurity outbreak in the country's history, and until now, Australia had been the last continent to remain free of the parasitic mite. The decision has been made by the National Management Group that it is no longer technically feasible to eradicate varroa mite. You can read the rest of the story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia abandons efforts to eradicate deadly parasite 15 months after biosecurity outbreak

featuredLink.title: Australia abandons efforts to eradicate deadly parasite varroa mite after 15 months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Joseph Dunstan Short-stay rental platforms, such as Airbnb and Stayz, will face a 7.5 per cent levy from 2025, the Victorian government has announced. Premier Daniel Andrews made the announcement as part of Victoria's housing statement, a policy document aimed at boosting housing supply. The document notes that short-stay rental sites have become a "popular feature" of Victoria's visitor economy, but they have reduced the availability of properties for longer-term use. "In Victoria, there are more than 36,000 short-stay accommodation places — with almost half of these in regional Victoria. More than 29,000 of those places are entire homes," the document states. "These are places that cannot be used for longer-term accommodation or rented out on fixed-term agreements — so it makes sense that they should provide some benefit toward the places that can." The 7.5 per cent levy will apply to revenue from the platforms and will go towards Homes Victoria, to fund the construction of social and affordable housing across the state, the document says. The levy on short-stay accommodation is the first in Australia, opening the possibility of other states following suit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victoria introduces 7.5 per cent levy on short-stay rentals

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Brazilian Navy says it has seized 3.6 metric tons of cocaine on a boat off the coast of Brazil's north-eastern Pernambuco state. That's almost the equivalent weight of two cars ! In a statement, the Navy said it had captured a small motor boat used for transporting people and cargo along the coast with five crew members heading to Africa. It comes after a series of operations held by the Navy to fight drug transportation along the country's coast. According to the Navy, more than 17 tons of cocaine have been seized since 2020. That's about as heavy as nine-and-a-half cars… and if you prefer animal weight comparisons, it's about the weight of 20 cows.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brazil's Navy seizes record quantity of cocaine

image.altText: Watercolour map of Australia showing low amounts of rainfall across the country with ocean in background.

title.children: In Australia, El Niño has been linked to some of the worst droughts in modern history. Here's how it works

image.altText: A group of women arrive at a hotel, surrounded by media.

props.synopsis: Spain's secretary for sport says 'we looked ridiculous as a nation', as the country's women's football team attends training camp despite an ongoing boycott.

title.children: 'We were obligated to come': Stony-faced Spanish stars forced to attend training despite ongoing boycott

image.altText: A building with a for sale sign on the window

props.synopsis: Australian shares are set to open slightly lower, while US markets and Wall Street prepare for a meeting with the Feds, where they will decide on rates.

title.children: Inquiry into bank closures in regional Australian begins

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB CEO Ross McEwan says there is "a very changing, dynamic world" at play. "If you take yourself back 30-40 years, it was all done in branch and every branch was its own little bank," he says. "Today that world is completely different. "The vast majority of our customers are not doing it through a branch network." He's added the world is changing "dramatically". "I think you need to think about this more as a point of presence as opposed to a physical manifestation of a branch."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Today the world is completely different'

children.content: NAB CEO Ross McEwan says there is "a very changing, dynamic world" at play.
"If you take yourself back 30-40 years, it was all done in branch and every branch was its own little bank," he says.
"Today that world is completely different.
"The vast majority of our customers are not doing it through a branch network."
He's added the world is changing "dramatically".
"I think you need to think about this more as a point of presence as opposed to a physical manifestation of a branch."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Linda White is asking the NAB team which statistics they have int erms of branch usage and what raw data they look at in terms of visitation statistics. Senator White: "What's the value you put between the over the counter transactions versus these business transactions? When you weigh it up, how are you weighting them?" Krissie Jones has replied it's "not a formula" but a range of factors. "We look at a range of factors, whether that's over the counter, the types of inquiries the customers coming in but also the way that they're banking." After more grilling, Mr McEwan has stepped in to rebuff "assumptions made that we're looking for reasons to close branches". "That is not the case," he said. "We are there to serve our customers but there comes a point where not enough are coming into a branch to actually make their services viable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Range of factors' determine bank branch closures

children.content: Senator Linda White is asking the NAB team which statistics they have int erms of branch usage and what raw data they look at in terms of visitation statistics.
Senator White:
"What's the value you put between the over the counter transactions versus these business transactions? When you weigh it up, how are you weighting them?"
Krissie Jones has replied it's "not a formula" but a range of factors.
"We look at a range of factors, whether that's over the counter, the types of inquiries the customers coming in but also the way that they're banking."
After more grilling, Mr McEwan has stepped in to rebuff "assumptions made that we're looking for reasons to close branches".
"That is not the case," he said.
"We are there to serve our customers but there comes a point where not enough are coming into a branch to actually make their services viable."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac CEO Peter King is now being grilled on whether the bank is meeting its "social licence" in terms of letting volunteer organisations or community groups complete in-person transactions and signatures. He's taking a question on notice as to "shifting the cost" to Australia Post and how much Westpac saves when it closes down a branch. "I don't know, that's a question for Australia Post, but we just renegotiate that contract," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Social licence' on in-person banking

children.content: Westpac CEO Peter King is now being grilled on whether the bank is meeting its "social licence" in terms of letting volunteer organisations or community groups complete in-person transactions and signatures.
He's taking a question on notice as to "shifting the cost" to Australia Post and how much Westpac saves when it closes down a branch.
"I don't know, that's a question for Australia Post, but we just renegotiate that contract," he says.
